items.title: Earth exceeds Paris Agreement warming limit for first time

featured_image.name: 2025 will be world's second or third-hottest year on record, EU scientists say

items.description:
For the first time since nations pledged to limit global warming, the three-year average temperature has exceeded the 1.5°C threshold set by the 2015 Paris Agreement, scientists reported in a study released Sunday. The period spanning 2023 to 2025 marks a critical milestone in the acceleration of climate change, with 2025 ranking as one of the three hottest years on record[1][2][3][4].

The findings from researchers at World Weather Attribution, published December 29, underscore how human-induced climate change made 2025 one of the warmest years ever documented, despite the presence of La Niña conditions that typically cool global temperatures[1][5]. The European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service reported that November 2025 saw global temperatures reach 1.54°C above pre-industrial levels[3][4].

"If we do not cease the burning of fossil fuels very quickly, it will become exceedingly difficult to achieve that warming goal," said Friederike Otto, co-lead of World Weather Attribution and a climate scientist at Imperial College London[1]. "The scientific evidence is becoming increasingly unequivocal."

items.title: China nears completion of world's largest liquid air battery

featured_image.name: China to power up the world's largest 'super-cold air battery' in the ...

items.description:
China's groundbreaking liquid-air energy storage plant in the Gobi Desert has entered its final commissioning stage, marking a major step forward in the country's push to integrate intermittent renewable energy into its power grid. The facility, located near Golmud in northwestern Qinghai Province, is nearly ready for operation as of late December 2025, though full commissioning is expected in 2026[1][2][3][4].

The 60-megawatt plant, known as the Super Air Power Bank, represents the world's largest liquid-air energy storage installation. Built by China Green Development Investment Group in partnership with the Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, the facility can deliver up to 600,000 kilowatt-hours of electricity per discharge cycle, running for 10 hours straight[1][2][3][4]. Once operational, it will generate approximately 180 million kilowatt-hours annually—enough to power 30,000 homes[1][2][3][4].

items.title: Helsinki scientists create low-energy carbon capture compound

featured_image.name: Direct Air Capture of CO2 to Increase 150-Fold By 2024

items.description:
University of Helsinki scientists have unveiled a carbon dioxide capture technology that could significantly reduce the energy requirements for removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, potentially transforming direct air capture efforts worldwide.

The breakthrough, published December 3 in Environmental Science & Technology, centers on a novel compound that captures CO2 from ambient air and releases it at temperatures 13 times lower than conventional methods[1][2][3]. Postdoctoral Researcher Zahra Eshaghi Gorji developed the technology in Professor Timo Repo's chemistry department laboratory, where tests revealed that one gram of the compound absorbs 156 milligrams of carbon dioxide directly from untreated air[1][4][2].

"The ease of releasing CO2 is the key advantage of the new compound," Eshaghi Gorji said, noting that current carbon capture compounds typically require temperatures exceeding 900 degrees Celsius to release the captured gas[1][4][2]. By contrast, the new material releases clean, recyclable CO2 at just 70 degrees Celsius within 30 minutes[1][4][2].

items.title: Internal stress, not grain cracks, degrades EV batteries

featured_image.name: Why single-crystal EV batteries crack, fade, and sometimes fail

items.description:
Researchers have solved a puzzle that has been undermining electric vehicle battery performance: single-crystal lithium-ion batteries degrade through internal stresses, not the grain-boundary cracks that plague older designs. The finding, published December 23 in Nature Nanotechnology, could reshape how automakers approach battery safety and longevity[1][2][3][4].

Scientists at Argonne National Laboratory and the University of Chicago discovered that design rules developed for conventional polycrystalline batteries were being incorrectly applied to newer single-crystal materials, causing unexpected performance problems[1][5][6][2][3]. "If people don't trust batteries to be safe and long-lasting, they won't choose to use them," said Khalil Amine, Argonne Distinguished Fellow and co-author of the study[1][2][3][7].

items.title: Major soy traders set to abandon Amazon conservation pact

featured_image.name: The Amazon in 2025: Challenges and hopes as the rainforest ...

items.description:
Major soybean traders are preparing to abandon a landmark Amazon conservation agreement, Reuters reported Sunday, while new research warns the world's largest rainforest is transitioning to a climate state unseen on Earth for tens of millions of years[1][2][3][4][5].

The collapse of the Amazon Soy Moratorium, coupled with mounting evidence of ecological transformation, threatens to accelerate damage to a region already reeling from record fires and intensifying droughts. Companies including Cargill and Bunge are expected to withdraw from the 2006 pact to preserve tax benefits in Brazil's Mato Grosso state, which will strip incentives from conservation participants starting in January[3][5]. The moratorium, which bars traders from buying soybeans grown on land deforested after July 2008, is credited with curbing Amazon deforestation over nearly two decades[3][5].

items.title: SoftBank, Alphabet spend $9B on AI data centers

featured_image.name: Google Buys Data Center Company for $4.75 Billion

items.description:
Two major technology companies announced acquisitions totaling nearly $9 billion this week to bolster their artificial intelligence infrastructure, underscoring intensifying competition for the computing power needed to develop next-generation AI systems.

SoftBank Group revealed Monday it will acquire DigitalBridge Group for approximately $4 billion, including debt, paying $16 per share in cash[1][2][3]. The Japanese conglomerate's CEO Masayoshi Son framed the deal as essential to AI's future, stating, "As AI transforms industries worldwide, we need more compute, connectivity, power, and scalable infrastructure"[1][2].

The acquisition comes one week after Alphabet, Google's parent company, announced plans to purchase data center and energy infrastructure developer Intersect for $4.75 billion in cash plus the assumption of debt[4][5][6]. Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai said Intersect will help the company "expand capacity, operate more nimbly in building new power generation in lockstep with new data center load, and reimagine energy solutions to drive US innovation and leadership"[5].

items.title: Study suggests dark energy may be weakening, universe could collapse

featured_image.name: Evidence Mounts for Evolving Dark Energy, DESI Results Find

items.description:
Astronomers have ignited controversy with findings suggesting dark energy could be weakening over time, potentially setting the stage for a cosmic reversal that would see the universe collapse back into itself.

The research, published in November in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, challenges decades of scientific consensus that the universe will expand forever[1][2][3]. Professor Young-Wook Lee of Yonsei University in Seoul and his team discovered what they describe as a fundamental error in how astronomers have been measuring cosmic expansion, one that has masked dramatic changes in dark energy[4][5].

"The fate of the Universe will change," Professor Lee told the BBC in an interview published December 27[1][6]. "If dark energy is not constant and it's getting weakened, this will change the whole paradigm of modern cosmology."

items.title: Venezuela shuts oil wells as US blockade fills storage

featured_image.name: Venezuela starts shutting oil wells as US blockade halts flows

items.description:
Venezuela started shutting down oil wells in the Orinoco Belt on December 28, marking a desperate response to a US naval blockade that has left millions of barrels stranded and storage facilities at capacity[1][2][3]. The state-owned oil company Petroleos de Venezuela SA (PDVSA) plans to reduce production in the region by at least 25% to 500,000 barrels per day—a 15% cut to the country's total output of 1.1 million barrels daily[1][4][5].

The production cuts represent a critical turning point for President Nicolás Maduro, who has attempted to maintain oil exports that form the backbone of Venezuela's economy despite mounting US pressure. PDVSA approved the emergency plan on December 23, focusing first on the Junin area's extra-heavy crude operations before moving to the Ayacucho and Carabobo regions, which produce lighter grades[1][4][5]. Disabling wells is considered a last resort due to the operational challenges and substantial costs required to restart them[1][6].

items.title: Iran developing chemical warheads for missiles, sources say

featured_image.name: Protests, strikes after Iran's economic situation rapidly deteriorates

items.description:
Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps is developing chemical and biological warheads for ballistic missiles even as the country faces mounting domestic unrest over a collapsing economy, according to military sources cited by Iran International.

The outlet reported Sunday that the IRGC Aerospace Force has accelerated work on unconventional missile payloads alongside upgrades to command-and-control systems, with missile launchers being repositioned to eastern Iran[1][2][3]. The development, if confirmed, would mark a significant escalation in Iran's strategic posture and raise alarms in Washington and Jerusalem, particularly as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago on Monday to discuss Iran's missile program[4][5].

The report comes as Iran grapples with severe economic turmoil that has driven merchants and shopkeepers into the streets for a second consecutive day. On Monday, December 29, security forces fired tear gas at protesters in Tehran's Grand Bazaar and surrounding commercial districts as demonstrations intensified over soaring inflation and a currency in freefall[6][7][8].

items.title: Trump warns Iran against rebuilding nuclear program

featured_image.name: Trump says US would back strikes against Iran’s missile programme

items.description:
President Donald Trump threatened renewed military action against Iran on Monday if Tehran attempts to rebuild its nuclear capabilities, declaring the United States would "knock the hell out of them" during a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago[1][2][3].

Speaking alongside Netanyahu, Trump claimed joint U.S.-Israeli operations had already destroyed Iran's nuclear program and fundamentally shifted the Middle East balance of power. "We just won a big war together," Trump said. "If we didn't beat Iran, you wouldn't have had peace in the Middle East. We wiped it out"[1][3].

When pressed on whether he would support further Israeli military strikes if Iran continues advancing its missile or nuclear programs, Trump responded affirmatively. "If they continue with the missiles — yes," he said. "The nuclear — absolutely"[1][2][3].

items.title: Kazakhstan oil output falls 6% after Ukraine hits Russia export terminal

featured_image.name: Kazakhstan tells Ukraine to stop attacking CPC terminal after oil exports halted

items.description:
Kazakhstan's oil production fell approximately 6 percent in December following a Ukrainian drone strike that crippled a critical Russian export terminal, forcing the Central Asian nation to scramble for alternative export routes and threatening billions in revenue[1][2].

The country's oil and gas condensate output dropped to 1.93 million barrels per day between December 1 and 28, down from November averages, according to an industry source cited by Reuters [1][2]. Production at the Chevron-operated Tengiz oilfield, Kazakhstan's largest, plummeted 10 percent to 719,800 barrels per day during the same period[1][2].

items.title: China launches major drills around Taiwan after record US arms sale

featured_image.name: China stages record drills designed to encircle Taiwan

items.description:
China commenced its largest military exercises around Taiwan on Monday, deploying army, navy, air force and rocket units in what Beijing characterized as a "stern warning" following the Trump administration's approval of a record $11.1 billion arms package to the self-governed island earlier this month.

The "Justice Mission 2025" exercises mark the sixth major round of drills since 2022 and involve live-fire operations across seven zones surrounding Taiwan, simulating blockades of key ports and strikes on land and maritime targets[1][2][3]. Senior Colonel Shi Yi of the People's Liberation Army's Eastern Theater Command said the drills target "Taiwan independence separatist forces and external interference"[1][4][5][6][7].
